author: Kirsten Korosec
title: 10 Outlandish Amazon HQ2 Bids That Didn‚Äôt Work | Fortune
text:
By Kirsten Korosec January 18, 2018 
Amazon has culled its list of potential sites for its second headquarters from 238 bids across North America to just 20. And that means a lot of sad local lawmakers and economic development officials are milling about their respective offices. Especially considering the lengths to which some cities went to capture the prized second headquarters location. 
Here‚Äôs how far some cities‚Äîincluding some that made the first cut‚Äîwent to woo Amazon and the $5 billion campus the e-commerce company says it wants to build and fill with 50,000 new, full-time employees. Anywhere, Missouri 
Really. Just put it anywhere in the state. Gov. Eric Greitens made a bold suggestion to Amazon: chose the state for its second headquarters and a futuristic high-speed and unproven transit system called Hyperloop could be built to connect its two largest cities St. Louis and Kansas City. Birmingham, Alabama 
Three giant Amazon boxes the size of trucks were placed around Birmingham and residents were encouraged to share their photos on social media by using the hashtag ‚Äú#bringatob.‚Äù 
The city also installed two giant buttons built to resemble Amazon Dash‚Äôs instant-ordering units. When people press them, one of 600 different promotional and even flirty tweets were sent out onto the web. Birmingham is Sagittarius and Amazon is Cancer. We were made for each other. #BringAtoB 
‚Äî Bring A to B (@BringAtoB) December 14, 2017 
One tweet said: ‚ÄúAmazon, we got a 100% match on Bumble. Wanna go on a date?‚Äù Birmingham asks the company in one of hundreds of Tweets it has sent the company.‚Äù Another one said ‚ÄúWe are Chipotle and these other cities are Taco Bell, Amazon.‚Äù #Bham 's the place to be for rising millennials. We topped the list of best cities for millennial entrepreneurs. #bringatob 
‚Äî Bring A to B (@BringAtoB) December 7, 2017 Calgary, Canada 
Calgary wanted to make sure Amazon got its message. So in October the Calgary‚Äôs economic development group erected a 120-ft. by 10-ft. banner at construction site near the retailer‚Äôs Seattle headquarters with the slogan ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not saying we‚Äôd fight a bear for you ‚Ä¶ but we totally would.‚Äù 
Other ‚Äúcheeky, bold messages‚Äù intended to break through the clutter of bids from other cities appeared in chalk on nearby pedestrian sidewalks, the city‚Äôs economic development group said in a release at the time. Charlotte, North Carolina 
Basketball legend Michael Jordan wrote a personal letter to Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos in a pitch for Charlotte, North Carolina. 
Jordan, a former University of North Carolina and Chicago Bulls superstar, owns the NBA‚Äôs Charlotte Hornets franchise and has deep roots in the state. The letter was included in Charlotte‚Äôs official bid for HQ2. 
Charlotte mayor Vi Lyles also made an effort to bring attention to the city. She declared Oct. 18‚Äîthe day before the bids were due‚Äîto be an official Amazon-themed day in the metro area called #CLTisPrime Day. Chula Vista, California 
The city offered to Amazon 85 acres of land for free, which has a value: $100 million. It also said it would excuse any property taxes on the headquarters for 30 years for a $300 million value. Fresno, California 
This city took their pitch to a new level and actually proposed giving Amazon direct control over how civic dollars were spent. 
Fresno promised to put 85% of all taxes and fees generated by Amazon into a special fund , which would be overseen by a board. The board, comprised of people from Amazon and the city, would determine how the money would be spent. The money would go towards housing, roads and parks in and around Amazon. Frisco, Texas 
The city, located about a half hour from Dallas, offered to give away 40% of its land area. 
‚ÄúOur city‚Äôs only about 60 percent built out, so we‚Äôve got a lot of available land where we can build to suit,‚Äù Mayor Jeff Cheney told the New York Times . ‚ÄúWe play to win. We‚Äôre innovators. We‚Äôre forward thinkers, and we‚Äôre serious.‚Äù Kansas City, Missouri 
Kansas City‚Äôs mayor Sly James wanted to get the retailer‚Äôs attention, so he bought 1,000 Amazon products on Wednesday, and reviewed each and every one of them. Let‚Äôs rake this one in, KC. Tell Amazon what you love about KC with a tweet using #KC5Stars . pic.twitter.com/FCDChEXJYB 
‚Äî Mayor Sly James (@MayorSlyJames) October 16, 2017 
Stonecrest, Georgia 
The suburb of Atlanta proposed de-annexing up to 345 acres of land and renaming it Amazon. 
‚ÄúThere are several major U.S. cities that want Amazon, but none have the branding opportunity we are now offering this visionary company,‚Äù Mayor Jason Lary said, according to a local NBC affiliate . ICYMI: The city of Stonecrest wants to change their city name to Amazon. (SEE WHY HERE) https://t.co/dMCzh6imEO pic.twitter.com/j6IXthPHU9 
‚Äî Everything Georgia (@GAFollowers) October 4, 2017 Tucson, Ariz. 
In September, a Tucson economic development group sent a giant 21-foot saguaro cactus to Amazon‚Äôs headquarters in Seattle. The company rejected the gift, tweeting to the group Sun Corridor Inc., ‚Äúunfortunately we can‚Äôt accept gifts (even really cool ones) so we donated it to the Desert Museum.‚Äù The Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum is a 98-acre zoo and natural history museum focused on the plants and animals of the Sonoran desert located west of the city near Saguaro National Park (west).
